Line 1: Line 1:
<!-- DEFINITION AND MEDIA HYPE -->
<!-- DEFINITION AND MEDIA HYPE -->
â
'''Prenatal cocaine exposure''', or PCE, occurs when a pregnant woman uses [[cocaine]] and thereby exposes her [[fetus]] to the [[drug]]. An estimated 0.5â3% of pregnant women worldwide use cocaine.<ref name="PMID20159194">{{cite pmid|20159194}}</ref> '''Crack baby''' was a term coined to describe children who were exposed to [[crack cocaine|crack]] (cocaine in smokable form) as fetuses; the concept of the crack baby emerged in the US during the 1980s and 90s in the midst of a great deal of media surrounding crack.<ref name="NPR"/> Early studies reported that people who had been exposed to crack in utero would be severely emotionally, mentally, and physically disabled; this belief became common in the scientific and lay communities.<ref name="NPR"/> Fears were widespread that a generation of crack babies were going to put severe strain on society and social services as they grew up. Later studies failed to substantiate the findings of earlier ones that PCE has severe disabling consequences; these earlier studies had been methodologically flawed (e.g. with small [[sample size]]s and confounding factors). Scientists have come to understand that the findings of the early studies were vastly overstated and that most people who were exposed to cocaine in utero are normal. <ref name="NPR"/> Eg.- Brandon Lee is a Crack Baby. <ref name="DUCK">
+
'''Prenatal cocaine exposure''', or PCE, occurs when a pregnant woman uses [[cocaine]] and thereby exposes her [[fetus]] to the [[drug]]. An estimated 0.5â3% of pregnant women worldwide use cocaine.<ref name="PMID20159194">{{cite pmid|20159194}}</ref> '''Crack baby''' was a term coined to describe children who were exposed to [[crack cocaine|crack]] (cocaine in smokable form) as fetuses; the concept of the crack baby emerged in the US during the 1980s and 90s in the midst of a great deal of media surrounding crack.<ref name="NPR"/> Early studies reported that people who had been exposed to crack in utero would be severely emotionally, mentally, and physically disabled; this belief became common in the scientific and lay communities.<ref name="NPR"/> Fears were widespread that a generation of crack babies were going to put severe strain on society and social services as they grew up. Later studies failed to substantiate the findings of earlier ones that PCE has severe disabling consequences; these earlier studies had been methodologically flawed (e.g. with small [[sample size]]s and confounding factors). Scientists have come to understand that the findings of the early studies were vastly overstated and that most people who were exposed to cocaine in utero are normal.<ref name="NPR"/>
<!-- EFFECTS IT DOESN'T HAVE -->
<!-- EFFECTS IT DOESN'T HAVE -->
Line 12: Line 12:
PCE is very difficult to study because it very rarely occurs in isolation: usually it coexists with a variety of other factors, which may confound a study's results.<ref name="Ackerman10"/> For example, pregnant mothers often use other drugs in addition to cocaine, or they may be malnourished and lacking in medical care. Children in households where cocaine is abused are at risk of violence and neglect, and those in foster care may experience problems due to unstable family situations. Thus researchers have had difficulty in determining which effects result from PCE and which result from other factors in the children's histories.
PCE is very difficult to study because it very rarely occurs in isolation: usually it coexists with a variety of other factors, which may confound a study's results.<ref name="Ackerman10"/> For example, pregnant mothers often use other drugs in addition to cocaine, or they may be malnourished and lacking in medical care. Children in households where cocaine is abused are at risk of violence and neglect, and those in foster care may experience problems due to unstable family situations. Thus researchers have had difficulty in determining which effects result from PCE and which result from other factors in the children's histories.
â
Brandon lee.
+
==Historical context==
  +
<!-- HOW IT EMERGED -->
  +
During the [[crack epidemic]] of the 1980s and 90s in the US, fear existed throughout the country that PCE would create a generation of youth with severe behavioral and cognitive problems.<ref name="Okie09"/> Early studies in the mid-1980s reported that cocaine use in pregnancy caused children to have severe problems including cognitive, developmental, and emotional disruption.<ref name="Thompson09"/> These early studies had methodological problems including small [[sample size]], confounding factors like poor [[nutrition]], and use of other drugs by the mothers.<ref name="Thompson09"/> However, the results of the studies sparked widespread media discussion in the context of the new [[War on Drugs]].<ref name="Doweiko08">[[#CITEREFDoweiko|Doweiko]] p.239</ref> For example a 1985 study that showed harmful effects of cocaine use during pregnancy created a huge media buzz.<ref name="Thompson09">{{cite pmid|19277053}}</ref><ref name="Ornes"/> The term "crack baby" resulted from the publicity surrounding crack and PCE.<ref name="Mercer09"/>
  +   +
<!-- POOR PROGNOSIS -->
  +
It was common in media reports of the phenomenon to emphasize that babies exposed to crack in utero would never develop normally.<ref name="Mercer09"/> The children were reported to be inevitably destined to be physically and mentally disabled for their whole lives.<ref name="NPR"/>
  +
<!-- SOCIAL EFFECTS -->
  +
Babies exposed to crack in utero were written off as doomed to be severely disabled, and many were abandoned in hospitals.<ref name="Vargas10"/> Experts foresaw the development of a "biological underclass" of born criminals who would prey on the rest of the population.<ref name="Ornes"/><ref name="Vargas10"/> Crime rates were predicted to rise when the generation of crack-exposed infants grew up (instead they dropped).<ref name="Vargas10"/> It was predicted that the children would be difficult to console, irritable, and hyperactive, putting a strain on the school system.<ref name="Goldberg228"/> Charles Krauthammer, a columnist from [[The Washington Post]] wrote in 1989, "[t]heirs will be a life of certain suffering, of probable deviance, of permanent inferiority."<ref name="Ornes"/><ref name="Vargas10"/> The president of Boston University at the time, John Silber, said "crack babies ... won't ever achieve the intellectual development to have consciousness of God."<ref name="Vargas10"/>
  +   +
<!-- THEORIES -->
  +
At the time, the proposed mechanism by which cocaine harmed fetuses was as a stimulantâit was predicted that cocaine would disrupt normal development of parts of the brain that dealt with stimulation, resulting in problems like [[bipolar disorder]] and [[attention deficit disorder]].<ref name="NPR"/> Reports from the mid 1980s to early 90s raised concerns about links between PCE and slowed growth, deformed limbs, defects of the kidneys and [[Genitourinary system|genitourinary]] and [[gastrointestinal tract]]s, [[neurological]] damage, [[microcephaly|small head size]], [[atrophy]] or [[cysts]] in the [[cerebral cortex]], [[intraventricular hemorrhage|bleeding into the brain's ventricles]], obstruction of blood supply in the [[central nervous system]].<ref name="Bauer05"/> Studies that find that exposure has significant effects may be more likely to be published than those that do not, a factor that may have biased reporting on the effects of PCE toward indicating more severe outcomes as the [[Crack epidemic (United States)|crack epidemic]] emerged.<ref name="Bauer05"/> Between 1980 and 1989, 57% of studies showing cocaine has effects on a fetus were accepted by the Society for Pediatric Research, compared with only 11% of studies showing no cocaine effects.<ref name="Volpe1025"/>
  +   +
<!-- EVOLUTION TOWARD TODAY'S VIEW -->
  +
After the early studies which reported that PCE children would be severely disabled came studies that purported to show that cocaine exposure in utero has no important effects.<ref name="Vargas10"/> Almost every prenatal complication originally thought to be due directly to PCE was found to result from confounding factors such as poor maternal nutrition, use of other drugs, [[major depressive disorder|depression]], and lack of [[prenatal care]].<ref name="Doweiko08240"/> More recently the scientific community has begun to reach an understanding that PCE does have some important effects but that they are not severe as was predicted in the early studies.<ref name="Vargas10"/> Most people who were exposed to cocaine in utero are normal.<ref name="NPR"/> The effects of PCE are subtle but they exist.<ref name="Bauer05"/><ref name="Messinger04">{{cite pmid|15173491}}</ref><ref name="Eiden09">{{cite pmid|18822371}}</ref>
==Pathophysiology==
==Pathophysiology==
[[File:Cocaine-from-xtal-1983-3D-balls.png|thumb|right|Cocaine is a small enough molecule to pass across the placental barrier into the bloodstream of the fetus.<ref name="Feng05"/>]]
[[File:Cocaine-from-xtal-1983-3D-balls.png|thumb|right|Cocaine is a small enough molecule to pass across the placental barrier into the bloodstream of the fetus.<ref name="Feng05"/>]]
â
Cocaine, a small molecule, is able to cross the [[placenta]] into the bloodstream of the fetus.<ref name="Feng05"/> In fact it may be present in a higher concentration in the [[amniotic fluid]] than it is in the mother's bloodstream.<ref name="Doweiko08241">[[#CITEREFDoweiko|Doweiko]] p.241</ref> The skin of the fetus is able to absorb the chemical directly from the amniotic fluid until the 24th week of pregnancy.<ref name="Doweiko08241"/> Cocaine can also show up in [[breast milk]] Brandon lee is a vagina.<ref name="Doweiko08241"/><ref name="Yaffe417">[[#CITEREFYaffe|Yaffe]] p.417</ref>
+
Cocaine, a small molecule, is able to cross the [[placenta]] into the bloodstream of the fetus.<ref name="Feng05"/> In fact it may be present in a higher concentration in the [[amniotic fluid]] than it is in the mother's bloodstream.<ref name="Doweiko08241">[[#CITEREFDoweiko|Doweiko]] p.241</ref> The skin of the fetus is able to absorb the chemical directly from the amniotic fluid until the 24th week of pregnancy.<ref name="Doweiko08241"/> Cocaine can also show up in [[breast milk]] and affect the nursing baby.<ref name="Doweiko08241"/><ref name="Yaffe417">[[#CITEREFYaffe|Yaffe]] p.417</ref>
Cocaine prevents the [[reuptake]] of [[neurotransmitters]] such as [[norepinepherine]] and [[epinepherine]], so they stay in the [[synapse]] longer, causing excitement of the [[sympathetic nervous system]] and evoking a stress response.<ref name="Volpe1025">[[#CITEREFVolpe|Volpe]] p.1025</ref> The [[euphoria]] experienced by cocaine users is thought to be largely due to the way it prevents the neurotransmitter [[serotonin]] from being reabsorbed by the [[presynaptic neuron]] which released it.<ref name="Feng05"/>
Cocaine prevents the [[reuptake]] of [[neurotransmitters]] such as [[norepinepherine]] and [[epinepherine]], so they stay in the [[synapse]] longer, causing excitement of the [[sympathetic nervous system]] and evoking a stress response.<ref name="Volpe1025">[[#CITEREFVolpe|Volpe]] p.1025</ref> The [[euphoria]] experienced by cocaine users is thought to be largely due to the way it prevents the neurotransmitter [[serotonin]] from being reabsorbed by the [[presynaptic neuron]] which released it.<ref name="Feng05"/>
